Yes - that is why you HAVE to remain unbiased, which is difficult, but I ca=
n do it.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Frank Sumption 
  To: EVP=
-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, April 13, 2009 12:24 PM
  Subject: Re=
: [EVP-ITC] Re: An alternative to the usual ghost hunter stuff.






   Th=
at's one reason why I've always said to watch out for your own expectation-=
-you can create the messages you're looking for. 

  Frank-S


  On Mon, Ap=
r 13, 2009 at 11:44 AM, John S <phenom_investigator@...> wrote:





=
    The problem we run into is what actually constitutes evidence of spirit=
 communication? This is the heart of the matter. As I said in the other thr=
ead, one cannot simply assume that unexplained information defacto proves s=
pirit communication or even external sources. 

    The reason is simple. I=
t is quite possible for internal and/or external influences to be exerted i=
n an experiment. Let us say you are doing an experiment and you are the onl=
y participant. We'll set aside the obvious challenge of reporting credibili=
ty for the moment. How do you truly know it's not you and even worse, how d=
o you know who in fact the external communicator is? Simply knowing facts i=
s not sufficient. Especially in cases where PK may be in play (such as the =
Ouija example) a remote PK agent could be influencing the planchette. Befor=
e ruling this out, consider that the very notion that anyone is moving anyt=
hing is problematic for many people. And spirit communication pushes the ed=
ge of the belief envelope for others. In the end, all of this is some form =
of anomalous phenomena. You could know things of which you are unaware. Con=
sider that you might be clairvoyant and not even realize it. If you were to=
 externalize this through a latent PK mechanism, bingo, you are the agent a=
nd the source of information. Yet to all appearances the information came f=
rom elsewhere and you therefore presume it must be external to yourself, wh=
ich in this example would not be true..



    I was taking advantage of th=
e physical nature of the experiment I proposed. Unfortunately this is what =
is required if one wishes to remove reliance on belief systems alone. This =
is what many in the field are looking for. From my own work with mediums an=
d other sensitives, I have learned the perils and the potential pitfalls wi=
th our own perceptual systems, memories and recall. All of this works again=
st us in even the most trivial experimental set up, which is unfortunate bu=
t true. This is yet one more reason to exercise caution with solely anecdot=
al experimental outcomes. You will find that independent historical validat=
ion is actualy pretty tricky, as I have said before, because it often is no=
t simply factual in nature. It tends to be more about emotions and feelings=
 and that's where specifically identifying an individual gets dicey.



   =
 I wish you all the best in your efforts, whatever path you may chose.



 =
     JS
